summary:

fullContent:
![Image](https://encrypted-tbn0.gstatic.com/images?q=tbn:ANd9GcSuT7av1hxJp9su_nkqZF1cN8D1FrzBSullJw&s)

To my Canadian friends, watching my Korean friends prepare for their careers sometimes feels surreal. While we typically explore various possibilities to find our passions, the job search in Korea looks like a giant survival game where everyone competes according to a set of rules.

"Spec": A Standardized List of Qualifications

Korean university students begin accumulating qualifications, known as "Spec," from the moment they enter college.
• Basic Requirements: A high GPA and a high score on a recognized English test (like TOEIC) are considered essential.
• Additional Requirements: Students also get extra certifications in areas like computer skills or Korean history. Many prepare for these exams out of anxiety, often saying, "Because everyone else is doing it."
• Experience Requirements: Winning awards in contests or having internship experience is a crucial competitive edge. Recently, these experiences have also become a must-have.
As a result, many applicants end up with resumes filled with similar certifications and experiences, rather than unique personal stories.

The Hiring Process: A Multi-Stage Filtering System

Once they have their "Spec," the hiring process involves multiple filtering stages.
• Document Screening and Aptitude Tests: It's common for applicants to apply to dozens of companies. If their documents pass the initial screening, they take a written test called an "aptitude test." This test evaluates a candidate's logic and problem-solving skills, and it was quite unique to me that applicants have to study separately for questions that don't seem directly related to the job.
• The "Used-Rookie" Preference: Due to the recent economic downturn, companies are increasingly preferring experienced workers even for entry-level positions. This is where the term "Used-Rookie" (Jung-go-sin-ip) comes from. These are applicants who apply for a rookie position but already have 1 to 3 years of experience from another company. From a company's perspective, they prefer these candidates because they can be immediately deployed for a task without any training costs, unlike a "fresh rookie" (ssaeng-sin-ip) with no experience. This puts recent graduates in a paradoxical situation: "They can't get a job because they have no experience, and they can't gain experience because they can't get a job."

Company Choices: Chaebols, SMEs, and IT Giants

Traditionally, Korean society has seen large corporations—or chaebols—like Samsung and Hyundai as the standard for a "good job," thanks to high salaries, stability, and great benefits. On the other hand, small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are often less preferred due to various practical reasons.
However, the younger generation has started looking at new options, specifically IT platform companies represented by "Ne-ka-ra-ku-bae" (Naver, Kakao, Line, Coupang, Baemin). These companies have emerged as new "dream workplaces," leveraging their relatively flexible organizational culture and high compensation.
This shift has also impacted popular job roles. Just a few years ago, "developer" was one of the most popular professions. But the situation has changed with the advent of generative AI. As the perception that AI can replace simple coding spreads, the demand for entry-level developers has decreased, and the "developer boom" has cooled off. Now, the job market's attention is shifting to highly specialized talent like AI/machine learning engineers and data scientists.

Workplace Culture: Organizational Norms vs. Personal Values

Life after getting a job also has many differences from Canada.
• Organizational Culture: Many companies still emphasize a vertical hierarchy and a group-oriented culture. After-hours "team dinners" are meant to build teamwork, but many young employees see them as an extension of work or an uncomfortable situation with their superiors.
• The Younger Generation's Response: The younger generation (Gen MZ) doesn't accept this culture unconditionally. They value "Work-Life Balance" (Worabel) very highly. Rather than dedicating their entire lives to a company, they tend to view their job as a contract to work a set number of hours for a salary. This has given rise to the concept of "Quiet Quitting." It’s about doing the bare minimum at work without deep involvement and using the extra time and energy for personal growth, like investments or a "side hustle."

Conclusion

In conclusion, Korea's job market is a highly systematic but complex ecosystem that comes with immense pressure. Especially with the recent economic downturn and rapid technological changes, young people are crafting their own survival strategies in an environment more unpredictable than ever. The clash between traditional corporate culture and the new generation's emphasis on personal values is a point of interest, as it will likely shape the future of Korea's workplace culture.

fr.fullContent:
![Image](https://encrypted-tbn0.gstatic.com/images?q=tbn:ANd9GcSuT7av1hxJp9su_nkqZF1cN8D1FrzBSullJw&s)

À mes amis canadiens, regarder mes amis coréens se préparer à leur carrière me semble parfois irréel. Alors que nous explorons généralement diverses possibilités pour trouver nos passions, la recherche d'emploi en Corée ressemble à un gigantesque jeu de survie où tout le monde concourt selon un ensemble de règles prédéfinies.

Le « Spec » : une liste standardisée de qualifications

Les étudiants universitaires coréens commencent à accumuler des qualifications, appelées « Spec », dès leur entrée à l'université.
• Exigences de base : Un bon dossier académique (GPA) et un score élevé à un test d'anglais reconnu (comme le TOEIC) sont considérés comme essentiels.
• Exigences supplémentaires : Les étudiants obtiennent également des certifications supplémentaires dans des domaines comme les compétences informatiques ou l'histoire coréenne. Beaucoup se préparent à ces examens par anxiété, disant souvent : « Parce que tout le monde le fait. »
• Exigences d'expérience : Gagner des prix dans des concours ou avoir de l'expérience en stage est un avantage concurrentiel crucial. Récemment, ces expériences sont également devenues un « must ».
En conséquence, de nombreux candidats se retrouvent avec des CV remplis de certifications et d'expériences similaires, plutôt que des histoires personnelles uniques.

Le processus d'embauche : un système de filtrage à plusieurs étapes

Une fois qu'ils ont leur « Spec », le processus d'embauche se déroule en plusieurs étapes de filtrage.
• Sélection sur dossier et tests d'aptitude : Il est courant pour les candidats de postuler à des dizaines d'entreprises. Si leur dossier passe la sélection initiale, ils passent un test écrit appelé « test d'aptitude ». Ce test évalue la logique et les capacités de résolution de problèmes du candidat. Il est assez unique que les candidats doivent étudier séparément pour des questions qui ne semblent pas directement liées au poste.
• La préférence pour les « débutants expérimentés » : En raison du récent ralentissement économique, les entreprises préfèrent de plus en plus les travailleurs expérimentés, même pour les postes de débutants. C'est de là que vient le terme « débutant expérimenté » (Jung-go-sin-ip). Ce sont des candidats qui postulent pour un poste de débutant mais qui ont déjà 1 à 3 ans d'expérience dans une autre entreprise. Du point de vue de l'entreprise, ces candidats sont préférés car ils peuvent être déployés immédiatement pour une tâche sans frais de formation, contrairement à un « vrai débutant » (ssaeng-sin-ip) sans expérience. Cela place les jeunes diplômés dans une situation paradoxale : « Ils ne peuvent pas obtenir d'emploi parce qu'ils n'ont pas d'expérience, et ils ne peuvent pas acquérir d'expérience parce qu'ils ne peuvent pas obtenir d'emploi. »

Choix d'entreprise : Chaebols, PME et géants de la technologie

Traditionnellement, la société coréenne considère les grandes entreprises — ou chaebols — comme Samsung et Hyundai comme la norme pour un « bon travail », grâce à des salaires élevés, une stabilité et de bons avantages sociaux. D'un autre côté, les petites et moyennes entreprises (PME) sont souvent moins appréciées pour diverses raisons pratiques.
Cependant, la jeune génération a commencé à envisager de nouvelles options, en particulier les entreprises de plateformes informatiques représentées par « Ne-ka-ra-ku-bae » (Naver, Kakao, Line, Coupang, Baemin). Ces entreprises sont devenues de nouveaux « lieux de travail de rêve », tirant parti de leur culture organisationnelle relativement flexible et de leur rémunération élevée.
Ce changement a également eu un impact sur les rôles professionnels populaires. Il y a quelques années seulement, le métier de « développeur » était l'un des plus populaires. Mais la situation a rapidement changé avec l'avènement de l'IA générative. Alors que la perception que l'IA peut remplacer le codage simple se répand, la demande de développeurs débutants a diminué et le « boom des développeurs » s'est calmé. Désormais, l'attention du marché du travail se tourne vers les talents hautement spécialisés comme les ingénieurs en IA/apprentissage automatique et les scientifiques des données.

Culture du lieu de travail : normes organisationnelles vs. valeurs personnelles

La vie après l'embauche présente également de nombreuses différences par rapport au Canada.
• Culture organisationnelle : De nombreuses entreprises mettent encore l'accent sur une hiérarchie verticale et une culture de groupe. Les « dîners d'équipe » après les heures de travail sont censés renforcer le travail d'équipe, mais de nombreux jeunes employés les considèrent comme une prolongation du travail ou une situation inconfortable avec leurs supérieurs.
• La réponse de la jeune génération : La jeune génération (génération MZ) n'accepte pas cette culture sans condition. Ils accordent une grande importance à l'équilibre vie privée-vie professionnelle (Worabel). Plutôt que de consacrer leur vie entière à une entreprise, ils ont tendance à considérer leur emploi comme un contrat pour travailler un nombre d'heures défini en échange d'un salaire. Cela a donné naissance au concept de « démission silencieuse » (Quiet Quitting). Il s'agit de faire le strict minimum au travail sans s'impliquer profondément et d'utiliser le temps et l'énergie supplémentaires pour le développement personnel, comme des investissements ou une « activité secondaire ».

Conclusion

En conclusion, le marché du travail coréen est un écosystème très systématique mais complexe qui s'accompagne d'une immense pression. Surtout avec le récent ralentissement économique et les changements technologiques rapides, les jeunes créent leurs propres stratégies de survie dans un environnement plus imprévisible que jamais. Le choc entre la culture d'entreprise traditionnelle et l'accent mis par la nouvelle génération sur les valeurs personnelles est un point d'intérêt, car il façonnera probablement l'avenir de la culture du lieu de travail en Corée.

fullContent:
**1. Seoul District Population Rankings (As of July 2025)**
The total population of Seoul is estimated at approximately 9.336 million people. The population distribution across the districts is as follows:

Top 3 Most Populous Districts:

1st: Songpa-gu (~648,000 people)

2nd: Gangnam-gu (~557,000 people)

3rd: Gangseo-gu (~554,000 people)

These three districts alone account for about 18.84% of Seoul's total population.

Top 3 Least Populous Districts:

25th (Last): Jung-gu

24th: Jongno-gu

23rd: Yongsan-gu

These areas are primarily located in downtown Seoul, and their low residential population is due to a high concentration of offices and commercial facilities.

**2. Percentage Breakdown by Rank**
Based on Seoul's total population of approximately 9.336 million, here is the percentage for each of the top-ranked districts:

1st Songpa-gu: ~6.94%

2nd Gangnam-gu: ~5.96%

3rd Gangseo-gu: ~5.93%

**3. The Difference in Foreigner Resident Ratios**
In contrast to the overall population rankings, the distribution of foreign residents shows a different pattern.

1st in Foreigner Ratio: Jung-gu

Jung-gu has the lowest total population among all districts, yet its foreigner resident ratio is the highest in Seoul, at about 8.64%.

Top Districts by Number of Foreigners:

Yeongdeungpo-gu and Guro-gu have the highest number of foreign residents, with about a quarter of Seoul's total foreign population living in these two areas.

Districts with a Low Foreigner Ratio:

Districts with large overall populations, such as Nowon-gu and Yangcheon-gu, have a relatively low percentage of foreign residents.

In conclusion, while Seoul's population is heavily concentrated in the southeast and Gangnam regions, the distribution of foreign residents is different, being concentrated in downtown areas or specific living zones.

1. Nationwide Weather Overview (September 22 - September 28, 2025)
This week, Korea's weather is expected to be very pleasant as it fully enters the autumn season. The weather will be generally clear, but be prepared for a large daily temperature difference between morning and evening.

Early Week (Mon-Tues): The entire country will enjoy a clear and bright sky. Daytime temperatures will be in the mid-20s°C, perfect for outdoor activities, but morning and night temperatures can drop to the low 10s°C, feeling quite cool.

Mid to Late Week (Wed-Sun): Under the influence of a high-pressure system, clear weather is expected to continue. There is no significant rain in the forecast until the weekend, so the pleasant and cool autumn weather will persist.

2. Weather by Major City

title: Why Lotte World is a Must-Visit This Autumn
fullContent:
![Image](https://adventure.lotteworld.com/image/2020/6/202006010125571450_1350.jpg)

****Lotte World**** is the ultimate autumn destination, offering a perfect mix of thrilling rides, beautiful scenery, and world-class entertainment. As the summer heat fades and the leaves begin to change, the park transforms into a magical wonderland that offers something for everyone.

Enjoy the 2025 Halloween Festival
The biggest reason to visit Lotte World in the fall is its famous Halloween Festival, which runs from September 12 to November 3. The park brilliantly splits its atmosphere into two distinct themes: one for the daytime and one for the night.

Happy Halloween (Daytime): During the day, the park is a cheerful, family-friendly celebration. You'll find charming photo zones filled with pumpkins and ghosts, along with a lively Halloween Character Parade. It's the perfect time to visit with kids and make wonderful memories.

Horror Halloween (Nighttime): Once the sun sets, Magic Island becomes a chilling horror zone. Get ready for an adrenaline rush with signature attractions where zombies come to life, chasing guests for a truly terrifying experience. The nighttime is complete with eerie lighting and special effects that ramp up the fear.

Embrace the Perfect Autumn Atmosphere
Beyond the exciting Halloween events, Lotte World offers a fantastic fall experience thanks to its beautiful surroundings and ideal weather.

Great Weather for Rides: The hot, humid summer is gone, making your visit much more comfortable. The cool, crisp air is perfect for enjoying all the outdoor rides on Magic Island without long, sweaty waits.

Stunning Scenery at Seokchon Lake: Lotte World is located right next to Seokchon Lake. As autumn arrives, the trees surrounding the lake turn vibrant red and yellow, creating a breathtaking backdrop for the park's iconic castle. It's a fantastic spot for a leisurely stroll and a must-have for your travel photos.

Practical Tips for Your Visit
Special Foreigner Discount: Lotte World offers discounts for foreign visitors. You can get a discounted one-day pass by showing your passport or Alien Registration Card at the ticket booth. The price is approximately ₩43,000 to ₩50,000, which is about $45-55 CAD.

Tip: You can often find even better deals by booking in advance through online travel platforms like Klook.

Address: 240, Olympic-ro, Songpa-gu, Seoul

Hours: Daily from 10:00 AM to 9:00 PM (Check the official website, as hours can change.)

Guide Map: You can plan your route efficiently by checking the official guide map before your visit.
https://adventure.lotteworld.com/kor/usage-guide/service/guide-map/contentsid/375/index.do

Official Website: For the latest information on parade times and ride schedules, it's best to check the official Lotte World website before you go.

Visit on a Weekday: If your schedule allows, a weekday visit in the fall is a great way to avoid weekend crowds and enjoy shorter wait times for rides.

1. Details of the Temporary K-ETA Exemption Policy

Extension of Exemption Period: The temporary K-ETA exemption, initially implemented for the "2023-2024 Visit Korea Year," has been extended for another year until December 31, 2025, to further boost tourism.

Eligible Countries: The exemption applies to citizens of 22 countries and regions, including Canada, the United States, Japan, the United Kingdom, France, and Germany.

Important Note: Although the K-ETA is waived, travelers can still voluntarily apply for it to receive benefits such as skipping the arrival card submission upon entry. However, a fee will be charged in this case, and previously issued K-ETAs can be used until their expiration but are not refundable.

2. Related Issues and Controversy

The K-ETA exemption has been positively received for attracting tourists but has also raised several issues.

Tourism Industry's Welcome vs. Ministry of Justice's Concerns: The Ministry of Culture, Sports and Tourism has actively pushed for the extension to boost tourism. In contrast, the Ministry of Justice has been cautious due to concerns about a potential increase in illegal immigrants and a decrease in tax revenue. A particular controversy arose with some countries, like Thailand, where a disagreement between tourism promotion and illegal immigration issues prevented them from being included in the exemption list.

Travelers' Confusion: The sudden changes and uncertainty surrounding the policy's extension have caused confusion for some travelers, disrupting their travel plans. Travel agencies have also faced difficulties in planning tour packages to Korea due to the policy's unpredictability.

fr.fullContent:
1. Détails de la politique d'exemption temporaire du K-ETA

Prolongation de l'exemption : La mesure d'exemption temporaire du K-ETA, initialement mise en place pour l'« Année de la visite en Corée 2023-2024 », a été prolongée d'un an, jusqu'au 31 décembre 2025, afin de stimuler davantage le tourisme.

Pays éligibles : L'exemption s'applique aux citoyens de 22 pays et régions, dont le Canada, les États-Unis, le Japon, le Royaume-Uni, la France et l'Allemagne.

Note importante : Bien que le K-ETA soit exempté, les voyageurs peuvent choisir de le demander volontairement pour bénéficier d'avantages, comme l'exemption de remplir la carte d'arrivée à l'immigration. Des frais seront toutefois facturés. Les K-ETA déjà émis restent valables jusqu'à leur date d'expiration, mais ne sont pas remboursables.

2. Problèmes et controverses liés à la politique

L'exemption du K-ETA a été bien accueillie pour son potentiel à attirer des touristes, mais elle a également soulevé plusieurs questions.

L'accueil de l'industrie du tourisme contre les inquiétudes du ministère de la Justice : Le ministère de la Culture, des Sports et du Tourisme a activement plaidé en faveur de la prolongation pour relancer le tourisme. En revanche, le ministère de la Justice s'est montré prudent en raison de craintes concernant une augmentation possible des immigrants en situation irrégulière et une diminution des recettes fiscales. Une controverse a notamment éclaté avec certains pays, comme la Thaïlande, où un désaccord entre la promotion du tourisme et le problème de l'immigration illégale a empêché leur inclusion dans la liste des pays exemptés.

Confusion chez les voyageurs : Les changements soudains de politique et l'incertitude quant à sa prolongation ont créé de la confusion chez certains voyageurs, perturbant ainsi leurs projets de voyage. Les agences de voyage ont également eu du mal à planifier des offres de voyage en Corée en raison de l'imprévisibilité de la politique.

Haus Nowhere Seoul is more than just an eyewear store; it's a new concept cultural complex from GENTLE MONSTER’s parent company, IICOMBINED, that embodies the brand's innovative philosophy of blurring the lines between art and commerce. With a name that means "a house that does not exist," this space offers visitors a completely new, multi-sensory journey that goes far beyond a typical shopping experience.

Located in Seoul's trendy Seongsu-dong district, Haus Nowhere Seoul immediately captivates visitors with its exterior. Designed by architect Kim Chan-joong's firm, The System Lab, the building's Brutalist architectural style, with its exposed concrete and unique structural elements, makes it look like a massive sculpture that crash-landed in the city. Its cold, robust facade stands out, harmonizing with Seongsu-dong's unique, hip cultural vibe to establish itself as a new landmark.

Upon entering, visitors feel as if they've stepped into a colossal work of art rather than a retail space. Each floor is filled with diverse media art and experimental installations that visually express GENTLE MONSTER's aesthetic values. The brand's signature creative displays, along with the ever-changing art pieces, continuously provide visitors with fresh inspiration.

The uniqueness of Haus Nowhere Seoul extends to its multi-brand experience. In addition to GENTLE MONSTER, visitors can explore various brands from the IICOMBINED family. The first floor serves as a pop-up and project space, while the second floor showcases GENTLE MONSTER's eyewear. On the third floor, you'll find the beauty brand Tamburins and the fashion brand ATISU. The fifth floor is home to the dessert brand Nudake's "Tea House," where visitors can indulge in both art and gastronomy.

Haus Nowhere Seoul is a true cultural complex that weaves together architecture, art, and multiple brands into a single narrative. Here, visitors are free from the singular goal of shopping and can instead explore the space at their own pace, fully immersing themselves in the new aesthetic values that GENTLE MONSTER presents.

A K-pop Pilgrimage: The 8 Sights of Seoul
Naksan Park: Famous for its beautiful night views and walking trails along the old Seoul City Wall. It's a "pilgrimage" site for drama fans, as it's a frequent filming location for many K-dramas.

Gyeongbokgung Palace: The largest palace of the Joseon Dynasty, it provides a serene backdrop often used in historical dramas. Many tourists come here to take photos in hanbok to experience traditional Korean beauty.

Cheongdam Bridge: This two-tiered bridge over the Han River offers stunning views of the city skyline. The nearby Cheongdam district is considered the heart of K-pop, home to major entertainment companies like SM, JYP, and FNC, and the bridge itself often appears in music videos and dramas.

Samseong Station Billboards: The massive digital billboards at Samseong Station are a hub of K-pop fandom culture. Fans from all over the world buy ad space here to celebrate their idols' birthdays or comebacks, making it a must-visit spot for fans to take photos.

Bukchon Hanok Village: A traditional village with hundreds of hanok (traditional Korean houses). Its beautiful hanoks and narrow alleys create a unique atmosphere, often serving as a backdrop for dramas and films, attracting tourists who want to feel Korea's ancient beauty.

Myeongdong Street: A bustling shopping district filled with cosmetic stores, fashion boutiques, and street food stalls. It's a key tourist spot representing the vibrant, modern side of Seoul and is a popular filming location for dramas, perfect for shopping and food tours.

Jayang Station (Ttukseom Resort Station): Located near the Han River, this leisure spot offers beautiful scenery at Ttukseom Hangang Park. Its unique exterior has made Jayang Station a well-known spot among fans, as it often appears in K-dramas and music videos.

N Seoul Tower: Standing tall on Namsan Mountain, this iconic landmark offers a panoramic view of Seoul. It's a classic location in romance dramas, famous for the "love locks" on its observation deck, making it a "sacred site of love."

Le quartier voisin de Cheongdam est considéré comme le cœur de la K-pop, abritant de grandes agences de divertissement comme SM, JYP et FNC. The Evolution of Households: Seoul vs. Canada
1. Single-Person Households
Seoul: As of 2024, single-person households make up a remarkable 40% of all households, establishing themselves as the most common type. This is a rapid increase and a key trend in Korean society.

Canada: In the 2017 census, single-person households accounted for 28.2% of the total, becoming the most prevalent household type for the first time in history. While the rate is lower than in Seoul, the trend of growth is similar.

Key Difference: Seoul's rate of single-person households (40%) is significantly higher than Canada's (28.2%), indicating that the shift towards one-person living is accelerating much faster in Seoul.

2. Aging and Elderly Households
Seoul: The population aged 60 and over has surpassed 20%, classifying it as a "super-aged society." There has been a sharp rise in single-person and couple households among the elderly.

Canada: While the senior population is growing, the proportion of single-person households for those aged 65 and older is actually decreasing. This is likely due to more elderly people choosing to live with their children or in other communal arrangements.

Key Difference: Seoul is experiencing a rise in single-person households alongside aging, whereas in Canada, the proportion of elderly living alone is decreasing despite an aging population.

3. Marriage and Divorce
Common Trends:

Rising Age of First Marriage: In both Seoul and Canada, the average age for a first marriage continues to rise for both men and women.

Increase in "Gray Divorces": While the overall number of divorces is declining in both regions, the average age for divorce has increased, with late-life divorces making up a significant portion of cases.

4. Other Household Types
Seoul: Households with young children and single-parent households are on the decline, a trend that reflects the country's low birth rate.

Canada: There has been a notable increase in couples without children, as well as a rise in legally recognized common-law partnerships and same-sex couple households.

Summary: Both Seoul and Canada are experiencing common social changes, such as the growth of single-person households and a rise in the age of marriage and divorce. However, Seoul is characterized by a much higher proportion of one-person households and a distinct trend of more elderly people living alone, while Canada shows a greater diversity in household structures, including common-law and same-sex partnerships.

Lévolution des ménages : Séoul vs. le Canada
1. Les ménages d'une personne
Séoul : En 2024, les ménages d'une personne représentent 40 % de l'ensemble des ménages, ce qui en fait le type de ménage le plus courant. C'est une tendance majeure et en forte accélération dans la société coréenne.

Canada : Lors du recensement de 2017, les ménages d'une personne représentaient 28,2 % du total, devenant pour la première fois le type de ménage le plus répandu. Bien que le taux soit inférieur à celui de Séoul, la tendance à la croissance est similaire.

Principale différence : Le taux de ménages d'une personne à Séoul (40 %) est nettement supérieur à celui du Canada (28,2 %), ce qui indique que cette évolution s'accélère beaucoup plus rapidement à Séoul.

2. Le vieillissement et les ménages de personnes âgées
Séoul : La population âgée de 60 ans et plus a dépassé 20 %, ce qui classe la ville dans la catégorie des "sociétés super-âgées". On observe une forte augmentation des ménages d'une personne ou des couples âgés.

Canada : Bien que la population de personnes âgées augmente, la proportion de ménages d'une personne âgée de 65 ans et plus a tendance à diminuer. Cela s'explique par le fait que de plus en plus de personnes âgées choisissent de vivre avec leurs enfants ou dans d'autres types de logements collectifs.

Principale différence : À Séoul, le vieillissement s'accompagne d'une augmentation des ménages d'une personne âgée, tandis qu'au Canada, la proportion de personnes âgées vivant seules diminue malgré le vieillissement de la population.

3. Mariage et divorce
Tendances communes :

Augmentation de l'âge du premier mariage : À Séoul comme au Canada, l'âge moyen du premier mariage continue d'augmenter pour les hommes et les femmes.

Augmentation des divorces tardifs : Bien que le nombre total de divorces diminue dans les deux régions, l'âge moyen du divorce a augmenté, avec une part significative des divorces se produisant plus tard dans la vie.

4. Autres types de ménages
Séoul : Les ménages avec de jeunes enfants et les ménages monoparentaux sont en déclin, une tendance qui reflète le faible taux de natalité du pays.

Canada : On observe une augmentation notable des couples sans enfants, ainsi que des partenariats légaux en union libre et des ménages de couples de même sexe.

Résumé : Séoul et le Canada connaissent des changements sociaux similaires, tels que la croissance des ménages d'une personne et l'augmentation de l'âge moyen du mariage et du divorce. Cependant, Séoul se caractérise par une proportion beaucoup plus élevée de ménages individuels et une tendance marquée à la solitude des personnes âgées, tandis que le Canada montre une plus grande diversité des structures de ménages, incluant les unions libres et les partenariats de même sexe.

The 2025 Gangnam Festival is scheduled to take place from September 25 to October 3, 2025, celebrating the 50th anniversary of Gangnam District. The festival will be held across the entire district, with main locations including COEX, Yeongdong-daero, and Maru Park.

Here is a breakdown of some of the key events:

Vision Declaration Ceremony & Opening Event: This will be held on September 26 at the east plaza of COEX, featuring performances and the announcement of Gangnam's future vision.

Yeongdong-daero K-POP Concert: The signature event of the festival is on September 27 on Yeongdong-daero, near the COEX East Gate. The lineup for this concert is set to include artists such as g.o.d, BTOB, FIFTY FIFTY, SF9, nSSign, and Baby DONT Cry.

HEY! Gangnam Family Concert: On September 28, this concert will feature stars from the 1990s, including Lee Jaehoon (Cool), Lim Changjung, and Kim Changryeol (DJ DOC).

Gangnam Fashion Festa: This event will showcase a hybrid show in collaboration with domestic fashion brands and artists.

Gourmet Journey & K-Culture Zone: From September 25 to 28, this zone will offer exhibitions and performances focused on K-food and global cuisine.

KBS Open Concert: On October 2, this concert will be held at Jamwon Hangang Park.

Gangnam International Peace Marathon: This event will take place on October 3.

HEY! Bongeun Temple Music Concert: The festival will conclude on October 3 with a musical performance at Bongeunsa Temple.

In addition to these main events, there will be various fringe performances, busking, and street events at locations like Gangnam Station, Garosu-gil, and Apgujeong Rodeo throughout the festival period.

The 2025 Gangnam Festival is a large-scale event, and while many of the festival's activities and performances are free to the public, some specific events or special packages, especially those targeting foreign tourists, have a cost.

Yeongdong-daero K-POP Concert: The concert itself is generally a free event. However, tickets for foreigners are often provided as part of a travel package. These packages, which can range from $35 to $150 USD or more, include a concert ticket along with a tour of Gangnam, K-beauty vouchers, and other related services. It is important to note that these packages are a way for foreign tourists to secure tickets, as direct ticket purchases are not available.

Other events: Many of the other programs, such as the fashion show, various street performances, and food zones, are likely to be free to attend for the general public.

![Image](https://cphoto.asiae.co.kr/listimglink/1/2025091507454532154_1757889945.jpg)

Le Festival Gangnam 2025 aura lieu du 25 septembre au 3 octobre 2025, célébrant le 50ème anniversaire de l'arrondissement de Gangnam. Les événements principaux se dérouleront à COEX, Yeongdong-daero, et Maru Park, ainsi que dans d'autres lieux du district.

Points forts du festival
Cérémonie d'ouverture et déclaration de la vision : Le 26 septembre, un événement d'ouverture se tiendra sur la place est de COEX, avec des spectacles et l'annonce de la vision future de Gangnam.

Concert de K-POP sur Yeongdong-daero : L'événement phare du festival est prévu pour le 27 septembre sur Yeongdong-daero, près de la porte est de COEX. La liste des artistes pressentis inclut des noms comme g.o.d, BTOB, FIFTY FIFTY, SF9, nSSign et Baby DONT Cry.

Concert familial HEY! Gangnam : Le 28 septembre, ce concert mettra en vedette des stars des années 1990 telles que Lee Jaehoon (Cool), Lim Changjung et Kim Changryeol (DJ DOC).

Gangnam Fashion Festa : Un défilé de mode hybride sera présenté en collaboration avec des marques de mode et des artistes locaux.

Zone Gourmet Journey & K-Culture : Du 25 au 28 septembre, cette zone proposera des expositions et des spectacles axés sur la cuisine coréenne et mondiale.

Concert public KBS : Un concert aura lieu le 2 octobre au parc de Jamwon Hangang.

Marathon international de la paix de Gangnam : Cet événement sportif se tiendra le 3 octobre.

Concert de musique HEY! Bongeunsa : Le festival se clôturera le 3 octobre avec un spectacle musical au temple de Bongeunsa.

En plus de ces événements majeurs, de nombreuses performances de rue et spectacles secondaires auront lieu dans des endroits comme la gare de Gangnam, Garosu-gil et Apgujeong Rodeo tout au long de la période du festival.

Le Festival Gangnam 2025 est un événement d'envergure, et bien que de nombreuses activités et spectacles soient gratuits pour le public, certains événements spécifiques ou forfaits spéciaux, notamment ceux destinés aux touristes étrangers, sont payants.

Concert de K-POP sur Yeongdong-daero : Le concert lui-même est généralement gratuit. Cependant, les billets pour les étrangers sont souvent inclus dans des forfaits de voyage. Ces forfaits, dont le prix peut varier de 35 à 150 USD ou plus, incluent un billet de concert ainsi qu'une visite de Gangnam, des bons de réduction pour la K-beauté et d'autres services connexes. Il est important de noter que ces forfaits sont le seul moyen pour les touristes étrangers d'obtenir des billets, car l'achat direct de billets n'est pas disponible.

Autres événements : La plupart des autres programmes, tels que le défilé de mode, les spectacles de rue et les zones gastronomiques, sont probablement accessibles gratuitement au grand public.
